prompt.body:
Lees de tekst.

Hi, my name is Salah. I'm going to tell you about my life.

I live in London. I live in an apartment with my mum and my three brothers. I don't have my own bedroom. I share it with my younger brother Badr. That's OK, we like each other. As soon as we get home, we play games on our console.

I like cooking. Sometimes I cook for the whole family.

My mum is a nurse and she cleans offices. I don't know where my dad is or what he does.

When I'm older, I want to have my own house. It has to be big enough for my family and it should be in a quiet area. I would like a house near the beach, because I love swimming in the sea!


Kies het goede antwoord.

Do you want to have even more fun at the London Zoo? Try our amazing 'Meet the Animals' experiences!

Get the chance to come even closer to our animals. One of our experienced zoo keepers will show you around and tell you all about our special 'guests'.

prompt.body:
Lees de tekst. Beantwoord daarna de vraag.

Showing animals

The first zoos kept their animals in separate cages or in areas with fences or walls around them. Most of them, however, did not like living alone, and they missed the excitement that they had in nature.

Today, zoos try to create an environment that is more natural to the animals and the visitors who watch them. It looks more like real nature, with rocks, plants and trees that animals would normally come across. Instead of cages, many zoos have large areas where animals can move around freely and do the things that they would also do in the wild.

Many zoos put animals of the same kind in the same areas. For example, lions, tigers and other large cats are often kept together. Animals that live in the same climate or biome, for example grasslands or deserts, are also sometimes grouped together.

In most cases, visitors can observe the animals but not touch them. Some exhibits use glass plates, others keep visitors and animals apart through rivers, pits or other natural barriers.

Hello, my name is Olga. I am studying at the University of Birmingham and I want to stay in touch with my family at home. So how do I do that?

Mostly I use my mobile phone, because it's the easiest way to call someone - my dad, my mum, my brother, my sister or my friends.

My parents like to see me when they talk to me, so we often use video calling, like Skype or Facetime. It's just easier to talk about private things if you can see each other, so I actually like that too.

I have modern grandparents who know to use a computer, so I usually send an email to let them know how things are going with their granddaughter!

prompt.body:
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

A Boy Made of Wood

Long ago in Italy there lived on old clock-maker named Geppetto. Tick-tick-TOCK! Tick-tick-TOCK! went all the clocks in his shop. When he worked, Geppetto felt happy. But when he rested, he felt sad. "Ah!" he thought. "I would so like a child to call my own!" So one day Geppetto carved a puppet from wood in the shape of a boy. "I will call you Pinocchio," said Geppetto. He put the puppet into a small bed.

That night, a big star swooshed right into Geppetto's room. It changed into a Blue Fairy! The Blue Fairy flew over to the little bed.

"Little wooden puppet," said the Blue Fairy. "In the morning, you will be able to walk and talk like a real boy." She tapped the puppet one time with her wand. "And if you can prove that you are brave and true, you will become a real boy."

Pinocchio's eyes opened.

Then the Blue Fairy went swoosh and was gone! Out of the window and up into the night sky.

When Geppetto woke up the next morning, he said, "I will go take my puppet out of bed." But the little bed was empty!

"Here I am, Father!" said Pinocchio from the other side of the room.

Geppetto turned around. "What? You can talk?"

"Yes! I am Pinocchio, your boy!"

Geppetto rushed over and swept the wooden puppet into his arms. "Pinocchio, my son!" he said happily.

Lees de tekst.

Smartphones are changing the shape of our skulls

Some smartphone users have noticed a small bump on their heads. It is big enough to feel by pressing it.

A scientist at a university in Australia, who has been a doctor for 20 years, told the BBC about the bump. He said that in the past ten years, he has found more and more patients with a bump like that. It is more common in 18- to 30-year-olds. It is probably the result of spending too many hours a day bent over their smartphones.

A study looked at the smartphone use of 1,200 people aged 18 to 86. It showed that younger people had more skull bumps. People who bend their necks while looking at their phones have a greater chance of getting a bump.

Bending your neck to look at your phone can strain the neck. Doctors call this strain "text neck".

Don't worry: the skull bump seldom causes health problems. And if your neck hurts, just change your sitting position.

Lees de tekst. Sleep daarna de juiste titel naar het juiste deel van de tekst.

Why having a mobile phone is a good thing

You hear all kinds of horror stories about why smartphones are bad for you. But we're forgetting that there are also good things about them!


When your parents were little, their parents often had no idea where they were. If something happened - for example, if they had a flat tyre on their bike - they had no easy way to contact their parents. But you have a smartphone! Your parents are only a text message or phone call away. That means you have more freedom but still feel safe.


Mobile phones make it easier to have a social life. You can stay in touch with kids that have the same interests. That is extra important for kids who live in places where there aren't many people the same age, or for kids with a handicap.


If you want to leave a sports event or a party earlier than planned and need a ride home, you can use your phone to call your parents. And if you are late and need to be picked up later, they can message or call. That way, nobody has to wait.


Digital technology is important in the modern world and children need to learn how to deal with it. With a phone they can learn to use apps, use a keyboard, and learn other useful skills.


You can use your mobile phone to find information for school projects and homework. Even some of your school 'books' are now online!

So the next time an adult starts talking about those 'bad' phones, you can tell them they're wrong!

Mr Spicer said his daughter loved the idea of setting up a stall near their home. "She just wanted to make people happy. She was really proud of herself," he said. "But after a while, four officers walked over."

"I thought that they would just tell us to pack up our things and go home. But they got all official said that she did not have a licence to sell things from a stall. My daughter started screaming, 'Daddy, Daddy, I've done a bad thing.' She's five."

"We got a fine of £150. We packed up our things and walked home."

A spokesman for the city council said: "We are very sorry that this happened. We want our officers to show common sense. This clearly did not happen. The fine will be cancelled and we have apologised to Mr Spicer and his daughter."

The teacher who changed my life

Evgeniy: 'The teacher who changed my life was Ms Gardener. She taught Science, but not in an ordinary way. She wanted to bring the subject alive for us, and that's exactly what she did. I still remember our project about Mars. Instead of just learning facts, we turned the whole classroom into the surface of Mars!

But what really changed me was the day we started a project about robots. I said to my friend Nika that I loved robots and was actually building one at home. Then Ms Gardener asked me to tell the whole class what we were talking about. So I told her, and she asked me all kinds of questions. Then she said: "Evgeniy knows more about this than I do. He is going to teach you today." And she sat down behind her desk.

At first I was a bit scared because I didn't know what to do. But then I told my classmates quickly how a robot works, wrote the steps for building a robot on the board and answered questions from other students. At the end of the lesson, Ms Gardener gave us an essay to write, based on my lesson.

When I left the classroom, I knew what I wanted to be: a teacher!'

Team Sports

Training in sports teams is the best way to become and stay fit. Team sport players have endurance and stamina, which means they can keep going for long periods of time without getting too tired.

Researchers looked into all the ways people stay fit. And by 'fit' they meant that people had strength, endurance and stamina. Cycling, running or swimming are all great activities to become and stay fit. Doing housework and climbing stairs was also good.

But researchers were interested to know if there were differences between individual sportspeople and team sport players. The study looked at 228 athletes. There were cyclists, bodybuilders, and basketball and football players. The researchers tested the athletes' power, their ability to jump, and their oxygen use.

'What we saw was that power athletes should do more endurance training and endurance athletes should do more power training,' said one researcher. 'Team players usually do both, and that's why they are generally fitter than individual sportspeople.'

content.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Aljaz: There's a table over there. Do you want to sit there?

Victoria: OK, but I'm still not looking forward to eating English food.

Aljaz: Don't worry, I had dinner here the last time I was here with my parents. It's good food.'

Victoria: So, what can I order?

Aljaz: Well, you can choose something from the menu. Or you can order one of the specials which aren't on the menu. They are on the board next to the bar over there. Or you can choose the standard three-course meal. It has a starter, a main and a dessert. It's cheaper than choosing dishes from the menu.

Victoria: It looks OK, but I don't want a starter and a dessert, that's too much for me. Are there any vegetarian mains?

Aljaz: Yes, there are vegetarian and vegan dishes on the menu as well. So we're going to skip the starter?

Victoria: Yes, I prefer a dessert to a starter! What would you like to drink? How about a cappuccino?

Aljaz: No, no cappuccino for me, I'm allergic to dairy. I'll just have tea. How about you?

Victoria: I'll be fine with water. I'm going to pay the bill, it's my treat.

Aljaz: We should split the bill. Pay half each.

Victoria: OK, but I'm going to leave the tip.

Aljaz: Are you ready to order now?

Victoria: Yes, I am!


Are the statements true or false?
Zijn de beweringen waar of niet waar?

1. Victoria has never had an English meal before. true / false
2. On the board you can find the standard three-course meal. true / false
3. Victoria does not eat meat. true / false
4. Aljaz hates coffee. true / false
5. Victoria has a tip for improving the restaurant. true / false

prompt.body:
Read the text.
Lees de tekst.

The government wants to make it illegal for UK restaurants to keep tips. In future, they will have to give them to their staff.

Many restaurants now keep the tips that customers put in tip jars. Only a few restaurants use the tips to pay workers. Restaurant worker salaries are very low and many of them need the tips to survive. Over two million people in the UK work in restaurants.

Many staff are happy with the new law because they are fed up with restaurants keeping their tips. Earlier this year, workers went on strike because of the low pay they get. The new law will make sure restaurant workers are treated fairly and get to keep all their tips. Restaurants say a new law is unnecessary because working conditions are fair.


Answer the questions.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

British holidays

British people usually have their holidays in summer, in July or August. Many working people take a two-week holiday during the summer. School children have time off from school from approximately the end of July to the start of September.

A second holiday break in winter or in spring is also becoming more popular in the UK. In winter some people go skiing in Europe, and in spring, visits to cities such as Paris, Amsterdam or Barcelona are popular.

The most popular foreign holiday locations for Brits include Spain, France, Greece and the USA. Lots of people buy a package holiday which includes flights and a hotel or an apartment. Because flights to warm places in Europe are cheap, many British people are able to spend two weeks a year relaxing in the sun abroad.

Flights and package holidays are much cheaper during school term time and the British government is worried that some young people are missing school to go on holiday. Parents who take their child on holiday during term time now risk a fine of up to 100 pounds.

Some British people also like destinations nearby, like England, Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales.

  1. Wanneer zijn scholieren in de zomer vrij?
  2. Waar gaan in de lente veel Britten naartoe?
  3. Wat houdt een 'package holiday' reservering in?
  4. Waar maakt de Britse overheid zich zorgen over?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

My last holiday

My last holiday was a two-week trip to Tanzania with my family. I had never been there before, but I'd heard a lot about it from my parents' friends, Monique and David, who live there.

We stayed in a few different hotels so we could see more of the country and its beautiful nature. It was truly amazing. On our first day there, we went to a local market in Arusha where they sold all the fruits and spices you can imagine. Moreover, everything was so cheap! I learnt a lot about the local culture and food. The next day we went on safari, which was why we went to Tanzania in the first place. In eleven days, we visited five different national parks. We saw elephants, zebras, lions, hyena's and so many more African animals.

On one of the last nights, we went to my parents' friends for dinner. They have mango and banana trees in their garden. How cool is that! They made us so much delicious food. We talked about their life in Tanzania and about all the wonderful things we saw on our trip.

  1. Hoe lang is de schrijver in Tanzania geweest?
  2. Wat heeft de schrijver op de eerste dag van de vakantie gedaan?
  3. Waarom ging de schrijver naar Tanzania?
  4. Bij wie is de schrijver op bezoek geweest?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

My house

My name is Izzy and I live in a detached house in a city called Brighton in the south of England with my mum, dad, older sister Pippa and our cat Lily. We have a small but nice garden. I even have a small plot in the back of the yard where I grow some fruits and vegetables. This spring I planted cucumber plants and a raspberry bush.

The kitchen is the heart of our home. It's quite big and there is a big table in the middle. Whenever we are home we spend most of our time in this room. We eat in there, we drink tea in there when Pippa and I get home from school and we do my homework there most of the time. Lily often sleeps on one of the chairs in the kitchen.

I used to share a bedroom with Pippa, but about a year ago we both got our own room. Pippa's room is bigger because she is older but I don't care. I like my room. It is cosy.

What I love about our house is that it is located near the beach. I can see the sea from the window in my room. In the summer we go to the beach all the time. In the winter it can be very cold here but I don't care. I love this house and hope we never move.

  1. In wat voor soort huis woont Izzy?
  2. Wat doet Izzy graag in de achtertuin?
  3. Waar maakt Izzy haar huiswerk?
  4. Wat zegt Izzy over haar kamer? Schrijf ten minste één opmerking op.
  5. Wat vindt Izzy het leukste aan haar huis?

values.value:
(0,2 punt per goed antwoord)

1 a detached house

2 grow fruit and vegetables

3 in the kitchen / at the kitchen table

4 een van de volgende antwoorden: it’s smaller than her sister’s room / she likes it / it is cosy / she can see the sea from her bedroom window.

5 That it is close to the sea.

content.body:
(0,2 punt per goed antwoord)

1 a detached house

Where do you get your news?

Alan, Canada
Where do I get my news? Well, when I lived in Canada I primarily got my news from watching television and reading the newspaper.
But since I moved to Asia, I find that my main source of news has become the internet. I often surf the web looking for various news sites. The TV and newspaper have become secondary sources for news.

Lucy, New Zealand
The only time in my life I read newspapers is when a professor or teacher asks us to read and bring an article to school. I don't think I've ever voluntarily read a newspaper. It's quite embarrassing but I prefer to watch TV, or listen to the radio to find out about news or things like that.

Thomas, The United States
Well, because I live overseas I get almost all of my news from the Internet, but I do buy magazines, like Time magazine and Newsweek and read them a little bit. I also buy the paper sometimes. When I'm home in America I really like to watch network news. I like the old network news, you know, the big TV stations that broadcast the 6 o'clock news.

Greg, The United States
As I am from the US I sometimes watch CNN but most of my news comes from different Internet news sources such as BBC. Now that I live in Japan, I also read newspapers such as the Daily Yomiuri and the Japan Times.

Friendship Day

Friendship Day takes place on the first Sunday of August every year. It is a day to be thankful for our friendships.

The tradition began in the USA in 1935. Shortly after that, the U.S. Congress declared Friendship Day as a national celebration. Since then, it has slowly spread around the world. However, it still has a long way to go before it is as popular as Mother's Day and Father's Day.

On Friendship Day, people spend time with their friends and exchange presents. Some people send cards, write special songs or bake friendship cakes. One great way to celebrate is to make a poster or create an album about your friend or friends.
Don't forget to include Winnie the Pooh in your celebrations, because the United Nations made Pooh the world's Ambassador of Friendship in 1997.

Friends are extremely important to us. Often, it can feel like they are family. In fact, many people spend more time with their friends than with their relatives. People also tell their friends more secrets. Everyone has special childhood friends, and some of these become lifelong friends. Best friends usually stay best friends forever.

Nowadays, the Internet has changed the way we make friends. Many people strike up friendships online. The Web is also useful to find long-lost friends. There are many sites to find old friends.

My life is complete now that I know you. My biggest wish is to make you happy and to make you smile every day. What I love most about you, is how kind you are to other people. You are the sweetest person I have ever known and you are so beautiful. I must be the luckiest person in the world to have you in my life.

Do you remember when we first met at school? The moment I laid eyes on you, I knew we were going to be friends. Recently, we have become much more than just friends. We are in love and everybody can know about us. Sometimes I want to shout from the rooftops how much I love you.

You always know how to make me laugh. Even when I am sad. I want to spend every moment of every day with you. When we are not in the same class, I miss you. When we go home at the end of the day, I can't wait until I see you again.

Because of all these reasons I want to ask you a question. Will you be my valentine?

Love,

How to exercise daily

Add these tiny bursts of exercise into your day to get healthier without even realising it. You don't even need to set foot in a gym! Fit exercise around your busiest days with these easy everyday tips.

1. Do a 10-minute workout before breakfast
If you can get up 25 minutes earlier, there's time to have a drink of water, do a 10-minute intense workout, and shower. Choose from hundreds of free videos on social media. Look for interval training, circuits, or a body weight workout.

2. Walk the longer way around
Popping to the shop or going to a friend? Take a slightly longer route. Just 5 minutes extra there and back will improve your health.

3. Walk to school or work
Can you walk at least part of your daily commute? Any extra walking will contribute to your daily step count. Walking burns calories, boosts your cardiovascular fitness, and helps to tone your legs.

4. Dance
When your favourite song comes on the radio, dance around the kitchen. You'll be surprised at how much it raises your heart rate!

5. An evening stroll
After dinner, use TV and online time to go for a walk instead. It's a great way to catch up with your family and talk about your day. Or you could use the time to listen to a podcast or audiobook.

[adapted from https://www.hollandandbarrett.com]

Rap music has taken over the world. I think that's amazing.

I was really into all kinds of music when rap first started. I thought it was interesting but never liked it enough to buy any rap. Several decades later, it has become a major music genre.

The big music awards now have a category for rap. Nowadays, most youngsters are into rap. They love the music and the fashion.

prompt.body:
Read the text about Daisy, the 'bat dog'. Answer the questions after reading the text.
Lees de tekst over Daisy, the 'bat dog'. Na het lezen van de tekst beantwoord je de vragen.

An abandoned puppy has a new home and a new job. The 7-week-old puppy was left at a baseball stadium in Georgia, USA last week. Someone found it crying in the parking lot. It had no name tag, collar or microchip.

The team put a message on its website about the dog, but the owner did not come forward. The team's president, Jared Orton, adopted the puppy and named her Daisy. The lucky pup also has a new job. She is the team's official 'bat dog'. A bat dog takes baseball bats to players, collects balls on the baseball field and pleases the crowd.

Mr Orton said Daisy looked very tired and a little lost. She was also hungry and dehydrated when he took her to the vet, but "was in pretty good health". He told reporters that she might be a little too small to hold a bat in her mouth. He said: "We aren't sure how big she'll get, so it's hard to say if she'll be able to pick up a bat."

He added that she will be a regular at the ballpark and will be popular with fans. She will also greet visitors every day at the team's office.

Mr Orton said finding Daisy was fate. He said: "It was just meant to be that we'd have a team dog as part of our staff."

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees onderstaande tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Elephants retire from a circus
It's described as "the Greatest Show on Earth". But now, after 145 years as the centrepiece of the Ringling Brothers' Circus travelling across the United States, the show's last remaining 11 elephants have arrived at a conservation centre in Florida to officially retire.

Meet Asia, the 48-year-old veteran entertainer who spent decades delighting crowds. She, and the other remaining 10, will spend their days outside from now on.

"It's been in the sense that after 145 years our elephants will no longer be a part of our travelling circus shows. It's the end of an era, its sweet in a sense and at the end of the day, it's about these magnificent creatures and conservation, and ensuring that these guys will be around for many generations to come."

Fewer than 40,000 elephants remain in the wild. Two hundred and fifty are in captivity in the United States, 39 of which are now at this 200-acre centre. The endangered Asian elephants have spent most of their lives in front of crowds of people, but while many may see this as an end of an era, others would argue it's time for a well-earned rest.

prompt.body:
Read the text Dressing for school. Sarah and John talk about which clothes students are and aren't allowed to wear in class. Answer the questions after reading the text.
Lees de tekst Dressing for school. Sarah en John praten over welke kleding studenten wel of niet in de klas dragen. Beantwoord na het lezen van de tekst de vragen.

Sarah: Okay, John, let's talk about fashion. You know, I have students and I think sometimes they don't dress appropriately for the classroom.

John: Oh yeah. Sometimes, it looks like students are wearing the clothes which they will plan to wear at night, to go out and go to a party with friends.

Sarah: Yeah. So actually, I think school uniforms are great. I would make the teachers wear the school uniform, too.

John: I agree with you.

Sarah: We can fix the problem by having a uniform for girls and boys and teachers, and we can feel like part of a team.

John: I know there are a lot of problems of school uniforms. First of all, students don't want to all dress the same. The boys wear pants and the girls have to wear a dress or a skirt. I don't think that's fair.

Sarah: I agree. I think a lot of schools these days they can let the girls choose. And so, the girls can wear shorts or pants.

John: There should also be some flexibility to wear a uniform, whether you want to wear shirts in a different colour, even if they're in the same style.

Sarah: Well, I had a student, and he came to class with a jacket. And it looks like a very expensive jacket but it had a very bad word written on the jacket.

John: Oh?

Sarah: And after class finished, I told him to, "Wait, please." And I told him that he probably shouldn't wear that jacket to class, or maybe, he shouldn't wear it anymore at all. It just isn't very appropriate.

And he came to class next time and he had the jacket but he had taken it to a shop and they had taken the bad word off of the jacket. And so, I was very happy to see that, that he changed his behaviour and now he could dress the way he liked but also be appropriate.

John: Well, that sounds very good. That's very effective.
